borough: London Borough of Barking and Dagenham
decision_conditions:
<p class="MsoNormal">Prior to the
commencement of development, an updated walkover survey shall be completed (during
the growing season (April to September)), to confirm the absence of Invasive
Non-Native Species (INNS) from the works area. Should INNS be identified, then
an updated Biodiversity Report outlining appropriate mitigation measures shall
be submitted to the Local Planning Authority for approval. The works shall
thereafter be completed in compliance with the details approved. <o:p></o:p></p><p>

</p><p class="MsoNormal"><i>Reason: To ensure
any potential ecological receptors that could pose a constraint to the proposed
development are adequately mitigated.&nbsp;<font face="Arial, sans-serif"><o:p></o:p></font></i></p>

<p class="MsoNormal">All non-road
transportable industrial equipment or vehicles which are fitted with an
internal diesel powered compression ignition engine between 37 and 560KW and
not intended for transporting goods or passengers on roads are required to be
NRMM registered and comply with the emission standards set out in chapter 7 of
the GLA’s supplementary planning guidance ‘Control of Dust and Emissions from
Construction and Demolition SPG’ July 2014. Such vehicles must be run on ultra
low sulphur diesel (also known as ULSD ‘cleaner diesel’ or ‘green diesel’).
"Ultra low sulphur diesel" means fuel meeting the specification
within BS EN 590. Where these standards are succeeded, they should be applied
no later than 1 year after succession. Exemptions to these standards may be
granted for specialist equipment or for equipment with alternative emission
reduction equipment or run on alternative fuels. Such exemptions shall be
applied for in writing to the LPA in advance of the use of such vehicles,
detailing the reasons for the exemption being sought and clearly identifying
the subject vehicles. Exemptions that are granted will be in writing and such
vehicles must not be used until written exemption has been received by the
applicant. <o:p></o:p></p><p class="MsoNormal">No vehicles or
plant to which the above emission standards apply shall be on site, at any
time, whether in use or not, unless it complies with the above standards,
without the prior written consent of the local planning authority. <o:p></o:p></p><p>



</p><p class="MsoNormal"><i>Reason: To
ensure that air quality is not adversely affected by the development and to
protect the amenity of future occupants and/or neighbours.</i><b><i><u><span style="font-family:&quot;Arial&quot;,sans-serif;mso-fareast-font-family:&quot;Times New Roman&quot;;
mso-fareast-language:EN-GB"><o:p></o:p></span></u></i></b></p>

<p class="MsoNormal">No demolition
or development shall commence until full details of the proposed mitigation
measures for minimising the impact of noise and vibration on sensitive
receptors in the form of a Noise and Vibration Management Plan (NVMP) have been
submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority. The Noise
and Vibration Management Plan (NVMP) shall include:</p><p class="MsoNormal">i) Best
Practice detailed within BS 5228:2009+A1:2014 ‘Code of Practice for Noise and
Vibration Control on Construction and Open Sites’ and BS 6187:2011 ‘Code of
practice for full and partial demolition’.</p><p class="MsoNormal">ii) Baseline
noise assessment – undertaken for a least 24-hours under representative
conditions to determine the pre-existing ambient noise environment. </p><p class="MsoNormal">iii) Noise
predictions and the significance of noise effects - Predictions should be
included for each phase of the demolition, and construction, vehicle movements
and an assessment of the significance of noise effects must be included based on the guidance in BS5228:2009+A1:2014 Annex E.</p><p class="MsoNormal">iv) Vibration
Predictions and the significance of &nbsp;&nbsp;effects - Predictions should be
included for each phase of demolition, and construction, and an assessment of
the significance of vibration effects must be included e.g., as per
BS5228:2009+A1:2014.</p><p class="MsoNormal">v) Noise
and vibration monitoring – Permanent real-time web enabled and/or periodic
noise and vibration monitoring must be undertaken for the duration of the
demolition and construction phases which may result in a significant impact.
The location, number of monitoring stations and the measurement data must be
agreed with the LPA prior to the start of construction.</p><p class="MsoNormal">vi) Community
engagement – The steps that will be taken to notify and update residents and
businesses that may be affected by the construction of the proposed
development.</p><p>





















</p><p class="MsoNormal"><i>Reason: To
safeguard noise sensitive premises and amenity.<font face="Arial, sans-serif"><o:p></o:p></font></i></p>

<p class="MsoNormal">No development
shall commence until full details of the proposed mitigation measures for
impact on air quality and dust emissions, in the form of an Air Quality and
Dust Management Plan (AQDMP), have been submitted to and approved in writing by
the Local Planning Authority. In preparing the AQMDP the Applicant should
follow the guidance on mitigation measures for sites set out in Appendix 7 of
the Control of Dust and Emissions during Construction and Demolition SPG 2014.
Both ‘highly recommended’ and ‘desirable’ measures should be included. The
applicant should follow the guidance on mitigation measures for Medium Risk as
a minimum.<o:p></o:p></p><p>

</p><p class="MsoNormal"><i>Reason: To
manage and mitigate the impact of the development on the air quality and dust
emissions in the area and London as a whole, and to avoid irreversible and
unacceptable damage to the environment (London Plan policies 5.3 and 7.14, and
the London Plan SPGs for Sustainable Design and Construction and Control of
Dust and Emissions during Construction and Demolition).<font face="Arial, sans-serif"><o:p></o:p></font></i></p>

<p class="MsoNormal">No development
shall commence until a Construction Environmental Management Plan (CEMP) and a
Site Waste Management Plan (SWMP) have been submitted to and approved in
writing by the Local Planning Authority. These Plans shall incorporate details
of:<o:p></o:p></p><p class="MsoNormal">a) construction
traffic management;<o:p></o:p></p><p class="MsoNormal">b) the parking
of vehicles of site operatives and visitors;<o:p></o:p></p><p class="MsoNormal">c) loading and
unloading of plant and materials;<o:p></o:p></p><p class="MsoNormal">d) storage of
plant and materials used in constructing the development;<o:p></o:p></p><p class="MsoNormal">e) the erection
and maintenance of security hoarding(s) including decorative displays and
facilities for public viewing, where appropriate;<o:p></o:p></p><p class="MsoNormal">f)&nbsp; wheel
washing facilities;<o:p></o:p></p><p class="MsoNormal">g) measures to
control the emission of dust, dirt and emissions to air during construction;
&nbsp;such measures to accord with the guidance provided in the document “The
Control of Dust and Emissions during Construction and Demolition”, Mayor of
London, July 2014; including but not confined to, non- road mobile machinery
(NRMM) requirements;<o:p></o:p></p><p class="MsoNormal">h) noise and
vibration control;<o:p></o:p></p><p class="MsoNormal">i)&nbsp; a
scheme for recycling/disposing of waste resulting from demolition and
construction works;<o:p></o:p></p><p class="MsoNormal">j)&nbsp; the
use of efficient construction materials;<o:p></o:p></p><p class="MsoNormal">k) methods to
minimise waste, to encourage re-use, recovery and recycling, and sourcing of
materials;<o:p></o:p></p><p class="MsoNormal">l)&nbsp; a
nominated Developer/Resident Liaison Representative with an address and contact
inaudible telephone number to be circulated to those residents consulted on the
application by the developer’s representatives. This person will act as first
point of contact for residents&nbsp;who have any problems or questions related
to the ongoing development;<o:p></o:p></p><p class="MsoNormal">m) a
biodiversity protocol for the site to prevent non-native species;<o:p></o:p></p><p class="MsoNormal">n) any external
lighting;<o:p></o:p></p><p class="MsoNormal">o)
access/egress, one-way system, and site management of vehicles<o:p></o:p></p><p class="MsoNormal">Demolition and
construction work and associated activities, other than internal works
inaudible outside the site boundary, are only to be carried out between the
hours of 08:00 and 18:00 Monday to Friday and 08:00 and 13:00 Saturday, with no
work on Sundays or public holidays without the prior written permission of the
Local Planning Authority.&nbsp;Any works which are associated with the
generation of ground borne vibration are only to be carried out between the
hours of 08:00 and 18:00 Monday to Friday.<o:p></o:p></p><p class="MsoNormal">Demolition and
construction work and associated activities are to be carried out in accordance
with the recommendations contained within British Standard 5228:2009, “Code of
practice for noise and vibration control on construction and open sites”, Parts
1 and 2.<o:p></o:p></p><p class="MsoNormal">Once approved
the Plans shall be adhered to throughout the construction period for the
development.<o:p></o:p></p><p>





































</p><p class="MsoNormal"><i>Reason:&nbsp;The
CEMP and SWMP are required prior to commencement of development in order to
reduce the environmental impact of the construction and the impact on the
amenities of neighbouring residents, and in accordance with policy BP8 of the
Borough Wide Development Policies Development Plan Document.<font face="Arial, sans-serif"><o:p></o:p></font></i></p>
The development hereby permitted shall be commenced before the expiration of three years from the date of this permission.
description: Pre-surcharging works at the former Barking Reach Power Station.
